regard.translation[0].definitions[0].def: respect and admiration for someone or something
regard.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The voters hold her in high regard (=respect or admire her).
Teachers are held in low regard in this society  (=are not respected or admired).
Jan’s regard for his great talent
Burt had high regard for his old law professor, Dr. Finch  (=he respected him a lot).
regard.translation[0].definitions[1].def: attention or consideration that is shown towards someone or something
regard.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: All students must have access to quality education without regard to wealth or class.
One must show proper regard for the law.
The present administration has demonstrated little regard for environmental issues.
She has no regard for other people’s feelings.
regard.translation[0].definitions[2].def: a long look without moving your eyes
regard.translation[0].note_box[0].headin: – Meaning 1: respect and admiration for someone or something
regard.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: The players have a very high regard for their manager.

have a high regard for somebody/something

regard.translation[0].note_box[1].headin: – Meaning 2: attention or consideration that is shown towards someone or something
regard.translation[0].note_box[1].sectio: Some motorists have no regard for other road users.

regard.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to think about someone or something in a particular way
regard.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Edith was widely regarded as (=considered by many people to be) eccentric.

regard.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: She stood back and regarded him coldly.
